I’m in the big blind with K♠6♥ facing a 4-bet from the small blind.

Hand details  
• Pot: 90 (10 my BB + 20 his SB + 60 raise)  
• To call: 70 more  
• Effective stack after call: 1400 behind (140 bb)  
• My holding: K♠6♥ – off-suit, mediocre kicker, no connectivity.

SPR if I call would be about 15.5 (1400/90), certainly deep enough that post-flop play will matter.

Preflop odds: I need to call 70 to win 160, so 30.4 % raw equity required. K6o vs a typical SB 4-bet range (roughly 15–17 %: 88+, A9s+, KJs+, AJo+, some suited broadway, occasional SC) has about 32–35 %. That’s barely the minimum and:

• Out of position the entire hand, often facing tough later streets.  
• Reverse implied odds: Domination by AK/KQ/KJ, plus any Broadway flop smashes villain.  
• Kicker issues dominate post-flop; playing for stacks with top-pair-bad-kicker deep is costly.

These factors make a call unprofitable in practice. Folding keeps the big stack intact and avoids a marginal OOP spot.
